div.head: THE DARDANELLES.
div.p: Our telegrams tend to show that Russia is about to seriously re-open the Dardanelles Question, as a preliminary to the departure of the Black Sea Fleet to the Far East. As the question is of considerable interest, a review of the existing situation will be timely. Under the Treaty of Paris the Black Sea was neutralised and the maintenance of either Russian or Turkish Fleets in its waters was forbidden. Under the Treaty of Berlin Rassia was allowed to maintain a Fleet in the Black Sea, but the passage of her warships through the Dardanelles and the Bosphorus was interdicted. When the Malacca was seized by a Russian Volunteer cruiser which had passed through the Dardanelles, the basis of the energetic. protest made by the British Government was thus stated in the House of Commons on the 20th of July by Mr. Balfour: "We took the strongest possible exception to that course on the ground that no ship of war could issue from the Black Sea, and, in our judgment, these members of the Volunteer Fleet, if they issued from that sea and then took bellige rent action, either had no right so to issue or no right to take action." Mr. Balfour added that "the Russian Government have met us in this matter-I will not say on the general principle but as regards the particular incident." The Russian official statement issued on the 2nd of August with reference to the Malacca completely ignored that which Mr. Balfour has described as the ground of the British protest, namely, "that no ship of war could issue from the Black Sea," and on the 9th of August it was unofficially notified from Constantinople that the Porte had agreed to accept Russian assurances as to the character of certain vessels of the Russian Volunteer Fleet which were to pass through the Dardanelles. These assurances were to the effect that the vessels were not to carry arms or munitions of war, that they were to fly the commercial flag "throughout the voyage," and that they were to go through the Straits separately and at intervals. The accuracy of this unofficial statement was confirmed by the Marquis of Lansdowne in the House of Lords on the 11th of August.

England's attitude in this matter is far from being one of unreasonable opposition to Russia. The French proverb which maintains that "ane porte"-it matters little whether it be spelt with a capital or not-"must either be open or closed" applies to this question. If the Dardanelles are to be free of entry to Russian warships, they must not be closed to those of Great Britain. Sir William White, the greatest of modern English Ambassadors at Constantinople, was ever of opinion that the best policy alike for Great Britain and for the world would be found in declaring the Dardanelles and the Bosphorus open water. The Sultan viewed this policy with the deepest apprehension, and latterly Russia shared his opinions. Obviously it was not a policy which could be carried out without the consent of all the signatories to the Treaty of Paris. Our material interest in the Near Eastern problem has waned so perceptibly of late years that it is almost extinct, but as a great naval Power we cannot assent to the grant to others of maritime privileges which are denied to ourselves. If Russian fleets are to be allowed, under whatever pretext, to pass freely from the Black Sea to the Mediterranean, our ships must enjoy the same facile access to the Black Sea. As a matter of practical politics, the status quo suits us as well as anything else, but if there is to be a modification it must be the same for all. But the question cannot be reopened at the present moment merely to suit Russia's convenience, and to allow the Black Sea fleet to pass the Dardanelles would be a grave breach of trust on our part towards our ally.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR.
div.p: TOKIO, December 3. A six hours' armistice was declared yesterday at Port Arthur for purposes of burying the dead.
The Russian fleet at Port Arthur evidently intends to make a sortie directly the harbour is untenable. Most of the ships are greatly damaged and unfit for service, though some are still intact.
The Russians are clearing away the mines with the object of maintaining an avenue of escape. (Reuter.)
An armistice was declared at Port Arthur on the 1st inst. to bury the dead. (Havas.)

div.p: General Kuropatkin reports several desperate hand-to-hand conflicts on a small scale along the Sha-Ho entrenchments. The Russians were
The Russians have received reinforcements and dislodged the Japanese from other villages. (Havas.)

div.head: THE JAPAN SE FLEET.
div.p: The Japanese have been hurriedly but effe ively overhauling their entire fleet with gre secrecy since August, in order to be in rea ness to meet the Baltic Fleet. The major of the Japanese vessels are now fully repair refitted, and repainted. (Reute

div.head: COALING OF BALTIC FLEET. SPAIN'S NEUTRALITY.
div.p: The Japanese Minister here asked Foreign Minister for explanations regard the coaling and provisioning of the B Fleet at Vigo. The latter replied to the ef that Spain had strictly observed her neutra (Reu

div.head: THIRD SQUADRON NECESSARY.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, December The Novoe Vremya again strongly the despatch of a third squadron, the rea being that the mastery of the sea is a nece for the Russians, and that the Baltic Fle too weak in comparison with the forces w will be opposed to it. (Ret

div.head: THE DESTROYER INCIDENT. ADMIRALTY RESPONSIBLE.
div.p: Messrs. Yarrow have written to the confirming generally the information publ by the Standard on the 22nd ult., and st that they had many opportunities of s two destroyers during the last four m but declined to do so for fear that belligerent secured them. They gave Admiralty ample notice of this particula The Times declares that the Admiralty i responsible, and demands an explanation remissness. (R

div.head: INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE STATUS OF HOSPITAL SHI
div.p: The International Conference, in Russia is participating, will open here 13th inst., and will consider the st hospital ships during war time.

div.head: THE DARDANELLES.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, December 3. The Russian Press is agitating for the opening of the Dardanelles to the Black Sea Fleet. The Novoe Vremya contends that only the Porte’s consent is necessary. The same journal contains an article, attributed to Captain Klado, one of the officers implicated in the Hall incident, in which the writer declares there is no fear of England causing trouble in the matter. She will probably make a great cutlery which will come to nothing, as she did in 1870, 1884, and recently in connection with the North Sea affair.

div.head: SUPREME PRIZE COURT. DECISIONS ON SEIZURES.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, December 3. The Supreme Prize Court has decided that the arrest of the German steamer Thea in July was not justified, but, as no appeal was made regarding the cargo, the Vladivostok judgment concerning the latter will stand. The Court also upheld Messrs. Dodwell and Co.'s appeal regarding the flour for Kobe, which was seized , on board the Arabia, mentioned on the 5th August, thus quashing the Vladivostok decision. Messrs. Dodwell and Company's case is most important because it involves the whole question of conditional contraband. (Reuter.)

ST. PETERSBURG, December 4. The owners of the S.S. Thea (which was sunk, and not arrested, as published yesterday) claim £39,000. The Court has justified the seizure of the S.S. Arabia, and confirmed the rest of the confiscations as regards cargo, seeing that appeals were not lodged. (Reuter.)

div.head: JAPANESE BUDGET.
div.p: TOKIO, December 3. The Budget submitted to the Diet on the 31st October amounts to about 1,000,000,000 yen, of which 780,000,000 is for the war, including the interest on the war loans. The economies on the ordinary expenditure amount to 120,000,000. It will be necessary in 1905 to borrow only 450,000,000.

div.head: RUSSIAN REFORM MOVEMENT. DISTURBANCE IN CAPITAL.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, December 4. The Reform movement throughout Russia is spreading. Friday's meeting here regarding the Press laws was interrupted by students who clamored for admission to the overfilled hall. They insulted the police, who eventually dispersed them by mounted gendarmes. (R.)

div.head: AMERICAN NAVY. TO BE SECOND TO NONE.
div.p: WASHINGTON, December 4. The annual report of the Secretary for the Navy recommends the formation of such a Navy as no other Power would desire to engage. The creation of two vice-admirals is suggested. The report points out that, owing to the absence of a vice-admiral on the Asiatic station, the United States must yield the leadership of any combined movement to nations having vice-admirals, should any crisis arise.

div.head: BUWPRAWERICAN COTTON CROP.
div.p: NEW YORK, December 3: The Government estimates the cotton crop at 12,162,000 bales, thus exceeding the highest anticipations. This news caused a sensation on the market. January quotations fell to 8. (R)

div.head: DUKE OF CONNAUGHT
div.p: Romr, December 4. The Duke of Connaught, who is here representing the King at the baptism of the Italian Crown Prince, will visit the Pope privately.
Rome, December 3. The state of health of the Duchess of Aosta is very disquieting,
ROME, December 4. The Duchess of Aosta is dangerously ill.
ROME, December 4. The Italo German Commercial Treaty has been signed.
Rome, December 4. The baptism of the Prince of Piedmont took place today at the Quirinal.
PARIS, December 4. M. Jaures has left for San Sebastian, where his duel with M. Déroulède will take place.

div.head: The American Yacht
div.p: Lysistrata left Port Said for Alexandria at 2 p.m. yesterday, after a long stay in harbor.

div.head: QUARANTINE
div.p: restrictions against arrivals from Jamnagar have been removed.

div.head: THE STEAM YACHT
div.p: Vectis, of the P. & 0. 1 Company arrived at Alexandria this afternoon with a number of tourists for Cairo.

div.head: THE BEYRAM HOLIDAYS
div.p: will be kept on Thursday, Friday and Saturday next, when all Government offices will be closed.

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS
div.p: Dogs found in the Esbekieh and Boulac districts of Cairo on the 6th and 7th inst. will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: GUIZEH PROVINCIAL COUNCIL.--
div.p: The Moudir of Ghirgeh Province will convoke the Provincial Council on the 19th inst.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE.--
div.p: An international variety and ballet company arrived at Alexandria from Milan yesterday and will open at this theatre on Thursday.

div.head: GAMBLING HELL RAIDED.-
div.p: The Alexandria police made a raid on a gambling hell in Attarin-street and arrested the owner, the cards and money being confiscated.

div.head: SANITARY DEPT.-
div.p: Messrs. Anastase Mimico, Charalambis G. Pylarinos, and Démitre G. Constantinidis have been authorised to practise as pharmacists,and Messrs. Hugh R. Magill, Mahmoud Sedki and Mohamed H. Oassef as surgeons.

div.head: BEYRAM VISITS.-
div.p: The Editor begs to acknowledge the receipt of P.T. 50 from Mr. Barker, Swedish and Norwegian Consul at Alexandria, as a dispensation from paying Beyram visits. The money will be sent to the Rudolph Home.

div.head: THE RED SEA CABLE
div.p: between Jeddah and Suakin is in & bad state of repair, and is often breaking. The Council of State of the Sublime Porte has ordered the Posts and Telegraphs Administration to undertake the repair of the cable in a scientific manner.

div.head: A BRANCH AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: of the National Bank of Greece will shortly be opened. This bank has also decided to establish agencies at Salonika, Smyrna, Constantinople, London, and Paris. Later on the bank will also found agencies at Adrianople and Bucharest.

div.head: THE BEAUTY
div.p: 'Show for children from 2 to 5 years of age belonging to members of the Cercle Artistique is to be held at 3 p.m. on Sunday, 18th inst. First and second prizes will be given for little girls and boys. Maids and nurses are strictly forbidden to accompany the children.

div.head: ROBBERY. -
div.p: Yesterday afternoon, some housebreakers broke into the residence of M. Quintavalle in the Bab el-Ghedid quarter of Alexandria, and stole everything they could lay their hands on, including £20 in silver and jewelry to the value of £30. No arrests have yet been made.

div.head: RABIES AT ALEXANDRIA.-
div.p: The Alexandria police are taking energetic measures to stamp out rabies, in the city. This evening all stray and ownerless dogs found in the Attarin and Custom House quarters will be poisoned, and on the 10th inst. similar operations will be carried out in the Ramleh and Minet-el Bassal quarters.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL: --
div.p: On the 1st inst., 12 vessels passed through the canal, of which 10 were British, 1 French, and 1 Austrian. The receipts for the day were frs. 289,055.55. On the 2nd inst., 19 vessels passed through. 13 were British, 1 French, 3 German, 1 Austrian, and 1 Dutch. On this day the receipts amounted to frs, 580,981.14.

div.head: A TRAM-CAR CONDUCTOR'S HONESTY.--
div.p: While one of our correspondents was in a car near the French gate at Alexandria harbor, he saw the conductor, No 172, restore a handkerchief with more than one pound sterling's worth of silver coins to & poor woman who had left it in the car. It would have been quite feasible for him to have kept this as when the woman left the car at the Labbane caracol nobody was in it.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUSEUM.-
div.p: During November last, 737 persons visited the Greco-Roman Museum, of whom 201 paid for admission. 70 visited "Pompey's Pillar," and 224 the Kom el Shougafa excavations. The Museum has lately been enriched by some terracotta and various utensils found in the hills of Alexandria. M. Maspero, Director-General of the Antiquities Service, has presented the Museum with some funerary stele and -20 Byzantine gold coins, while Baron J. de Menasce has given the Museum a block of green granite with inscriptions.

div.head: - A LOCAL SCULPTOR
div.p: is beginning to gain considerable reputation in Alexandria, on account of the remarkable portrait busts which he has executed. His name in Signor Piero Pusoni, and he has lately modeled some beautiful colossal busts of King Edward VII. in plaster, antique and modern bronze, and marble. The likeness is excellent and should form a handsome ornament for public halls, mess-rooms, clubs, etc. The cost of these beautiful masterpieces varies from £3 to £6. Bot Mr. Fusoni can execute other orders at prices varying in accordance with the requirements of his patrons.
EGYPT AND AMERICA. SIR ERNEST CASSEL'S MISSION. ".VERY IMPORTANT RESULTS.”

Sir Ernest Cassel is credited in some of the latest London morning papers to hand, with being in the United States on an enterprise connected with Egypt which is likely to have "some very important results." It was understood in other quarters, where less of mystery seems to attach to the movements of well known people, that Sir Ernest is merely absent on a holiday. Anyway, it the important enterprise story is true, it will doubtless be given to the public in due time,
The Duke of Connaught will probably pay a visit to Khartoum in January. English society papers state that the Duke and Duchess of Connaught are to do some antiquity digging this season.
Our Constantinople Correspondent, writing under date of the 29th ulto., remarks :

The Sacred Caravan of this year for Mecca embarked yesterday on board the Sakaria, of the Mahsussé Steam Navigation Co., for Beyrout. As you may know, the Sacred Caravan has been about a month in the village of Scutari, on the Bosphorus. A violent storm delayed her departure yesterday, the steamer sailed this afternoon. Osman Bey, in charge of the Sacred Caravan, went yesterday to Yildiz-Kiosk, in order to take leave of the Sultan.

Following on the note concerning the pilgrimage regulations, the Ministry of the Interior has issued a circular ordering the names and ages of all children under 4 years who are taken on the pilgrimage by their parents to be mentioned in the passport delivered by the moudirieh. Children over 4 years and the wives or mothers of pilgrims must be in possession of separate passports. Sums of P.T. 100 or P. T. 56 must be paid for children over 4 years for the expenses of the voyage, and for such children taken with the Mahmal the sum previously mentioned in the Journal Officier must be deposited.
Major-General Slade, C.B., General Officer Commanding, accompanied by the C.S.O., C.R.E., and A.D.C., left Cairo for Khartoum on inspection duty on Saturday.
During the absence, in the Sudan, of Major General Slade, the command of the troops in Egypt was assumed by Brig.-General G. M. Bullock, C.B.
Colonel C. Rawnsley, D.S.O., A.S.C., will command the garrison of Cairo.

Luxor, Sunday.---Major-General Slade arrived here this morning from Cairo by the express, accompanied by Colonel Colville, and proceeded an hour later to Assouan by the S.S. Toski, which came here specially for this purpose.
The following decisions were taken by the Council of Ministers at their meeting of Saturday, in addition to those mentioned in our Saturday's issue:
Nakhla Giorgi Efr., 2nd class 'substitut at the Native Tribunals, to be named 4th class judge at the Native Tribunal of Zagazig, to replace Abdel Wahab Fahmy Effendi, de ceased.

Three new native and three European judgeships are provided for in the Budget for 1905. The former will receive L.E. 800 and the latter L.E. 1,000 a year each. The total of the native' judges in receipt of
1,000 a year will be 11, and the number of European judges in receipt of LE. 1,200 & year is to be increased from seven to nine.

We are now in the last month of 1904, but some of the Ministries at Cairo have not published all their reports on 1903 yet. On Saturday last the Ministry of Public Works issued its report on the Corvée for 1903. The total number of men called out was 10,735, according to this report, but according to Lord Cromer's Report the number was 12,244.

div.head: OPENING OF SAVOY RESTAURANT.
div.p: The new Savoy Restaurant at Cairo opened for the first time on Saturday evening with great success. Several dinner parties were given, Sir Elwin Palmer having 15 guests, among whom we noticed Mrs, and Miss Slade, Mr. and Mrs. Graham, Mr. Carter Wilson, Lord Cecil, Mr. Vincent Corbett, Capt. Herbert, Capt. MacMurdo, Sir William Garstin, and Col. and Mrs. Asser.

We also noticed Mr. and Mrs. Glen Collins and party with Mr. Greville, Tueni Bey, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mond, Baron Felix de Menasce, Mr. B. de Guerville, Mr. and Mrs. Duveen, Mr. John Ross and two guests, etc.

The room was splendid and the variety and good taste of the decorations were much admired. During dinner the orchestra played, and after dinner there was a small private dance in which about 120 persons took part, including many officers of the Army of Occupation.

SUEZ TOURNAMENT. The annual tournament between Port Said and the Suez E.T.C. will take place on Thursday and Friday next at Suez. The events of Thursday include a football match in the afternoon, followed by billiards in the evening, Friday will be devoted to tennis.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H.H. the Khedive was present with the Ministers at the Leilet el Kadr ceremony which was held at the Citadel Mosque at 7.30 p.m. on Saturday

div.head: EGYPTIAN ENTERPRISE AND DEVELOPMENT CO., LTD.
div.p: This company has just been constituted and was authorized by official decree on the 26th ulto. The capital consists of 16,000 shares of L.E.1. each, subscribed as follows: Messrs. Georges A. Eid, 6,000, Ernest Rolin, 5,000, Habib Bey Ghanem, 1,500, Albert Nourisson Bey, 1,000, Hassan Bey Efilaton, 1,000, Léon Rolin, 500, Alexandre Ghanem, 500.

Mr. Eid is the managing director. The other members of the board are: Halib Bey Ghanem and Albert Nourrisson Bey, of Cairo, Mr. Ernest Rolin, of Brussels, and Edouard Thys, managing director of the Banque de Reports, de Fonds Publics et de Dépôts at Antwerp.
The objects of the society are thus described in the statutes : |

La Société & pour objet l'étude, la préparation et l'exécution, pour elle-même, pour compte des tiers ou en participation, des entreprises ou opérations suivantes, en vue de les réaliser soit par voie de vente, cession ou fusion, soit par leur constitution ou apport en Société, soit de toute autre manière : L'achat, la prise à bail, à loyer ou à ferme, la mise en valeur, l'exploitation, la location et la vente, de tous terrains ou immeubles urbains ou ruraux, la construction de canaux, réservoirs, digues, drains, la construction et l'exploitation de tramways, chemins de fer ou routes, les entreprises d'irrigation au moyen de machines élévatoires, les opérations industrielles se rattachant à l'exploitation agricole et à la transformation des produits du sol, telles que: distilleries, huileries, fabrication des engrais chimiques ou naturels et en général toutes affaires pouvant contribuer au développement des objets de la Société tels qui sont désignés, d'une manière non limitative.

Now that the financial fetters have been in great measure taken off Egypt, the Government can with easy mind engage in the grateful task of raising official salaries. The following increases will be authorized in the Budget :

Mansfield Pasha, L.E. 900 to 1,000; Capt. McMurdo, L.E. 1,000 to 1,200; Dr. Nolan, L.E. 540 to 860 ; Schalch Bey, L.E. 450 to 800 ; Paterson Bey, L.E. 550 to 600; Capt. Floyer, L.E. 550 to 600 ; Brugsch Bey, L.E. 650 to 700 ; Messrs. Legrain and Carter, L.E. 500 to 600; Omar Bey Loufti, L.E. 480 to 700 ; Mr. Wallich, L.E. 900 to 1,000; Liddell Bey, L.E.750 to 800; M.Imblon, L.E.780 to 840.
AMATEUR THEATRICALS IN CAIRO. = "THE PIRATES OF PENZANCE."

A performance of the opera The Pirates of Penzance is to be given at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, about the middle of January next, under the patronage of Lord Cromer and Major-General Slade, in aid of the funds of the Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the Soldiers and Sailors' Association, and the Soldiers' Benefit Fund.

A first rehearsal was held at the British Head Quarters on Saturday and was well attended. Among those taking part we noticed Mrs. Seldon-Wilmore, Miss Cox, Mrs. Roussin, Miss Delanoy, Mrs. Hornblower, Mrs. Micklam, Mrs. Merton, Miss Caillard, Mrs. Nolan, Mrs. Brook, Miss Simpson, Lieut. Powell, R.A., Lieut. James, R.E., Lieuts. Jennings Willock and Adams, R.I.F., Messrs. Cotterill, Courtenay Clifton, Adams, Trimen, Dr. Madden, Messrs. Webb, Temple, Merton, Brook, Roussin, Peacock, Swanston, etc., Major Delanoy, A.S.C., is to be stage manager, Lieut. Pranklin, E. A., musical director, Capt. Tucker, R.E., business manager, and Mr. Felix Powell takes charge of the box office.
Lieut. Franklin would be glad to hear of any instrumentalists willing to assist in the orchestra.
The next rehearsals will take place on Tuesday and Thursday next, at 5.15 p.m., at Head Quarters.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL
div.p: A general meeting of the members of the Khedivial Agricultural Society will be held at Cairo tomorrow afternoon, to discuss revision of the statutes, as drawn up after numerous consultations between the Government and the committee of the society.

A letter has been addressed to the president of the Society by the Government giving the statutes in their revised form and stating the objects of their revision. It is proposed that the moudirieh delegations should be substituted for those now existing in the moudirieh towns of Gharbieh, Sharkieh, and Minieh. These delegations are to consist of the Moudir, as president, the irrigation and sanitary inspectors of the moudiriehs, or their representatives, the ex-officio member of the general committee, representing the moudirieh, and two members representing the cultivators of each markaz of the moudiriehs, who will be selected by the executive committee of the society after consultation with the local authorities. The markaz representatives must be ordinary paying members of the society. A paid secretary shall be attached to each moudirieh delegation. This official shall be qualified fully in agricultural matters, and shall give the cultivators information regarding the work of the society, and general agricultural advice as to experiments that might be possibly undertaken in the moudirieh and shall actively participate in the distribution of seed, manure, etc. If it is decided, with the approval of the society, to carry out any useful agricultural work, he shall be entirely at the disposal of the local delegation for that purpose. These delegations are to meet monthly or, if necessary, more frequently, to discuss matters of agricultural interest. They shall keep the cultivators of the moudirieh fully informed as to the system in force for the distribution of seed and manure, and acquaint them with the aims and scope of the society's work in aid of cultivators generally. They shall also arrange for experiments to be made on the lands of cultivators, and shall be empowered by the society to collect the annual subscriptions of members, as well as other sums that may be due.

Under the present circumstances, competent secretaries for other moudiriehs are not available, but as opportunities occur, a gradual extension will be made in this direction, and the Govern- ment will, if necessary, consider the advisability of proportionately increasing the subvention, which, from January 1, will amount to L.E.3,000 annually, in addition to the subvention now granted. In the meantime, the society may engage students who have obtained their diplomas at the School of Agriculture, and these gentlemen, being placed on the society's experimental tarm and allowed to participate in the general work, will, in the course of a year or so, become competent to act as secretaries to additional moudirieh delegations. Meanwhile, the secretary of the delegation al- ready formed will visit the adjoining moudirieh whenever possible, for the purpose of giving advice on agricultural matters, and will re- spectively visit from time to time the eastern Delta, western Delta and upper provinces. Owing to the extension given to the work of the society, an assistant will be appointed to the present secretary, Mr. G. B. Foaden, who will be nominated secretary general.

Although the Government does not propose to establish an Agricultural Department, the formation of a Statistical Bureau for the col- lection of information and statistics relating to crop areas and agricultural returns is at pre- sent occupying its attention.

div.head:
CAIRO KUTTABS.
DISTRIBUTION OF GRANTS-IN-AID.
div.p: On Sunday morning the grants in-aid to the Cairo kuttabs were distributed in the amphitheater of the Ministry of Public Instruction, in the presence of Hussein Fakhry Pasha, Minister of Public Instruction; Yacoub Artin Pasha, Under-Secretary of State; Adly Pasha Yeghen, Governor of Cairo; Abd el-Halim Pasha Assem, Director-General of the Wakfs Administration; and Hussein Bey Rouchdy, Judge in the Mixed Tribunals.

The proceedings opened with a recital of a portion of the Koran, after which Sheikh Mohamed Cherif, one of the inspectors of the Ministry. read a report showing the progress accomplished during the past year. In Cairo there are 98 kuttabs under inspection for grants-in-aid. Of these 22 received a grant of the first class (P.T. 15 for each boy and P.T. 30 for each girl), and 68 received a grant of the second class, (P.T. 10 for each boy and P.T. 20 for each girl), the total amount of the grants-in-aid distributed to Cairo kuttabs being L.E.567. The highest grant earned by a kuttab was L.E. 22 mill. 500 and the lowes L.E. 1 mill. 900. The grants are apportioned between the fikis and arifs, the share of each fik being as a rule double the share of an arif. Among the teachers to receive a share of the grant were two female monitors (arifas). 88 of the kuttabs which received a grant-in-aid on this occasion were Mohamedan, and 2 were Coptic institutions.

The distribution of grants-in-aid, to the teachers of the kuttabs in the provinces will take place shortly in the chief towns of the various markazes. We trust that the provincial officials and leading inhabitants of the districts will take the same benevo- lent interest in the distribution of the grants- in-aid in their districts as was shown on this occasion by the Governor of Cairo and other officials.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Duke de Abruzzi will make a short stay in Cairo on his return from the Far East. He is expected to arrive at Port Said shortly.
The Dowager Countess of Lovelace has left London for Malta and Egypt.
We are glad to hear that Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, has quite recovered from his recent attack of influenza. He left to-day for Cairo to spend time in Beyram.
A marriage has been arranged, and will shortly take place, between Mlle Alice Aghion, daughter of Mr. and Mme Benjamin Aghion, and Mr. Joseph Cattaui of Cairo.
M. Leroux, general manager of the Sucreries et Raffineries Co., has been elected second deputy of the French nation at Cairo, in place of M. Oziol, who has become first deputy.
Rev. T. J. Finney, of the American Mission, arrived at Alexandria yesterday from America Mrs. Finney will remain at home another year with the family.
Mr. Wilfrid Carey has resigned the honorary treasurership of the Khedivial Agricultural Society.

Lieut. R. Wilson, R. G. A., will arrive at Alexandria from Malta about the 14th inst. and will proceed hence to Suez in time to embark on board the transport Plassy, sailing on the 20th idem, for passage to Bombay.

Among the latest arrivals at Mena-Hous Hotel are Lady Hervey-Bathurst, Mr. Reginal Hervey-Bathurst, Mr. W. G. Drew, Cap W. L. Beales, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Philipp Mr. P. H. div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Rameses sailed from Liv pool on Friday afternoon and is due hear about the 16th inst., with passengers, mails, a general cargo.
The Moss liner. Tabor arrived at Liverp on Saturday afternoon.

The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Niger, fr Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina Saturday and is due here tomorrow morning The S.S. Royal Prince left Manchester Friday with passengers and general cargo Malta and Alexandria..

TEWFIK PALACE HOTEL, HELOUAN.- management of this well-known hotel desire to bring to the notice of officers and resident Egypt the fact that the week-end arrangement of last season are in force for the pres season; also that specially reduced terms be charged those who may wish to stay at Tewfik Palace during the Beyram holidays réclame lunch is also served daily at 1 o'clock and on separate tables, at P.T. 12 only, further notice.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Commission Municipale s'est réanie le 3 Décembre 1904, à 9 h. du soir, sous I.. présidence de M. Ralli.

Présents: MM A. Ralli, président, Abdel Moneim bey Dalil, Mohamed bey Ayoub, G. B. Alderson, Hussein bey Risz, A. Cumbo, L. Escoffier, P. Fenderl, E. W. Foster, Mansour bey Youssef, Baron A. d Menasce, Michalla Pacha, Mohamed bey -Said, O. Bothaker, A. Padoa bey, Saleh bey Heddeni, Dr Schiess bey, E. Stross, Soliman bey Abani, T. Suzzarini, G. Zer- vadachi, membres, W P. Ohataway, administrateur, I. Sedky, secrétaire.
Mention est faite de l'envoi à tous les membres des procès-verbaux de la Délégation des 25 Octobre, 1er, 8 et 15 Nov. 1904.

Au sujet de cette communication, diverses observations sont formulées par M Escoffier, relativement à la question de la qualité de l'eau débitée en ville et de la fusion des services de perception de la Municipalité.

Communication est ensuite donnée de diverses lettres ministérielles, concernant l'application à Alexandrie du nouveau règlement sur les pharmacies, l'autorisation pour l'exercice de la profession, et pour l'ouverture des établissements, appartiendra à l'avenir, au Ministère sur avis de la Direction Générale des Services Sanitaires.

Sur la proposition de M. de Menasce, la Commission ouvre un crédit de L.E. 100, en vue de recouvrir de plantes grimpantes les talus bordant la promenade de Ramleb, jusqu'à l'Ibrahimieh, dépense à prélever Bur les excédents.
Elle prie le Dr Schiess de surveiller ces plantations.

A ce sujet, M. Cumbo attire l'attention sur les empiétements commis des deux. cô:és de cette route, depuis l'Ibrahimieh, par les cultivateurs riverains; les trottoire sont devenus si étroits, à la suite de ces. empiétements, que la circulation des piétons est presque impossible, d'autant plus que les espaces réservés autour des arbres pour leur arrosage, constituent autant de fondrières..
La Commission renvoie la question à la Délégation, pour les mesures à prendre. Lecture est ensuite donnée du rapport du Comité spécial, chargé d'étudier la question du Collecteur-Est..

Ce rapport conclat à la nécessité d'exé- outer ce collecteur mais depuis la Porta Rosette seulement; son raccordement avec les filtres s'opérera au moyen d'une conduite en fonte; de cette façon la dépense à engager, pour le moment, n'est que de 9400, au lieu da 12000 L E. prévues Ce colleotear servira en même temps, à drainer les eaux du quartier de la Porte Ro- Bette, qui se déversent actuellement à ciel ouvert dans le fossé des fortifications, constituant aini un danger pour l'hygiène publique.
A cet effet, le raccordement de l'égout de la porte Rosette au collecteur, doit être effectué en même temps que le travail principal.
La Commission adopte les conclusions du Comité, et décide de prélever la dépense Bur l'emprunt.

Ce travail sera mis en adjudication. Après un échange de vues, la Commis- sion nomme M. Chataway, à titre d'Admi- nistrateur, chargé de surveiller les opéra- tions de la Cie des Eaux, à l'égard des intérêts du public.

Mr. Rothakerse réserve de porter devant le Comité des finances une question con- cernant l'augmentation du capital de la Oie des Eaux, et l'influence que cette mesure pourrait avoir sur la participation éventuelle de la Municipalité, dans les revenus de cette Compagnie.

Sur la proposition de la Délégation, la Commission approuve les crédits suivants : L.E. 580, pour la construction de nou- velles chambres au dessus de la nouvelle aile de la Bibliothèque, devant servir aux besoins nécessités par l'extension des services.
LE. 100 pour aménag ments au Fort Kamarieh, en vue du service de la rage. Ces deux dépenses seront prélevées sur la réserve du budget extraordinaire.

Deux autres dépenses de 30 L. E. pour des gratifications aux percepteurs qui ont recouvré des taxes sur des bestiaux et véhicules non recensés en 1903, et de 80 L.E. pour souscription au nouveau diction- naire français-arabe, de Nagary bey, sont approuvées par voie de virements.
Sur la proposition de la Délégation, des virements divers de chapitres à autres du du budget, d'un montant de 776 L.E. sont approuvée.

Lecture est donnée de la pétition d'an groupe de locataires à Alexandrie, ainsi que de deux notes, l'une de Mr. Alderson et l'antre de Mr. l'Administrateur, au sujet de la question des logements à bon marché. Le Président exposé ses vues et propose à l'Assemblée d'adopter la motion de PAdministrateur tendant à la nomination d'un Comité par l'étude de la question. Après un échange d'observations entre divers memb es de l'Assemblée, la Com- missiery, péré rée de l'intérêt que présente u plus haut degré la question, mais tenue de ne pas dépasser la limite de ses ses attributions sur un sujet aussi complexe et d'ordre aussi général décide d'en référer au Gou- vernement par rapport à l'application à cette question de l'art. 15, page 7 du décret d'organisation Municipale.
Va l'heure avancée les autres questions à l'ordre du jour, sont ajournées à une prochaine réunion.
La séance est levée à minuit.

div.head: CAISSE DE LA DETTE
div.p: Echéance du ler Mars 1905: Le capital restant à amortir est de £7.982.100, la dotation d'intérêt de £119 781,10/ et la dotation d'amortissement de £97.768,10/; le total des deux dotations, £157.500, est égal à la demi-annuité à prélever le 15 février comme première charge sur les revenus affectés au service de la Dette Privilégiée et de la Datta Unifiée.
Echéance du 15 Avril 1905: Le capital ancien est de £29 393.580, et la nouvelle émission en verta du décret da 12 juillet 1900 de £1.734,200; soit au total £31.127.780.

D'autre part, le montant du coupon s'élève à £544,786 3/- et la moitié de l'éco nomie annuelle procurée par la conversion du capital ancien de la Dette Privilégiée et le remboursement de l'Emprant 4 1/2 0/0 à mettre en dépôt, à £185.916 9/4; soit un total de £680.652 12/4.
Le complément de dotations de la Dette Privilégiée est prélevé sur les revenus de la Dette Unifiée, y compris le report de l'exercice précédent.

Parmi les administrations dont les revenus sont affectés au service de la Dette Privilégiée, les Chemins de fer, Télégraphes et Port d'Alexandrie ont versé du 15 octobre su 30 novembre L.E. 292 500, le Ministère des Finances L.E. 15.093.669, ce qui avec le report de, L.E. 66.963,818, donne un total de L.E. 874.556,987.

Echéance du 1er Mai 1905: Le capital restant à amortir est de £ 55 971.960 et la dotation d'intérêt de £1.119.439 4/. Les provinces et administrations dont les revenus sont affectés au service de la Dette Unifiée ont versé du ler au 80 novembre les sommes suivantes : la province de Gharbieh L.E. 194.266,264, celle de Menoufien L.E. 80.000, celle de Béhé- ra L.E. 101.248,216 es dile de Siout L.E. 21.224,557, les Doaanes ont rapporté LE. 190.875,445, les droits sur les tabacs d'importation L.E 114.140 et les droits sur les sucres raffinés L.E. 6.000. Ces diverses sommes réunies au reliquat da 81 octobre, L.E. 1.982.543,819, forment un total de L.E. 2.690.292,801.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: The demand for Egyptian Cotton has been small, quotations are unchanged, with an easier tendency.
There has been a fairly active Market in Futures; the following are the latest values: Nov. 8.12 Jan. 7.47 Mar. 7.42 May 7.40 Dec. 7.54 Feb. 7.44 Apl. 7.41.

AMERICAN FUTURES. The Market this week has developed considerable weakness, and with some pressure to sell prices have fallen 21 to 24 points, the near positions being the weakest. The decline has been due to heavy Crop move- ments, which, together with the Ginners' reports to the 14th inst., have been used by the "Bears" to depress the various markets; at the same time the Southern Markets have been free sellers, and in consequence there has been daily a large amount of selling to hedge pur- chases. In our opinion the Market is now in a more healthy position; at 5d per lb. we consider the article is at a reasonable price, and although now or later on under the influence of increasing stocks prices may touch a lower figure, we believe the requirements of the world are so large after four starvation seasons that 5d. per lb. will prove a cheap basis, and that purchases round and about this price will, at sometime during the season, result profitably. The latest quotations are, delivery :-

div.p: Remarques sur le marché du disponible et

Disponible.-La demande a été assez bonne an début de la semaine, mais depuis que la baisse en Auérigne s'est sosentuée d'une faço au si marquée. Is dispositions des acheteurs se sont cilmées, les affaires sont tombées à un chiffes très réduit et, comme résumé, malgré la situation des contrats, c'est en baisse de 1/8 de talari pour le uit-Afifi et de 1/4 pour les provenances Hante-Egypte et Fayoum que la semaine se termine.

Les exportations sont légèrement inférieures à celles de l'année dernière et, t:ès probablement, il y aura une diminution a'térieure; mais, quand même, les engagements de décembre sont importants et les intéresés à la hausse espèrent qu'ils seront suffi. sants pour les aider à soutenir le marché.
Contrats.-Nouvelle récolte. O te nominale; les transactions isolées qui ont lieu de temps à autre ne peuvent servir de base exacte pour l'établis ement

Récolte actuelle: Le calme du disponible, le manque de demande de la part de la filature pour dates éloignées, les avis de l'Intérieur au sujet de la récolte qui font espèrer le maintien de l'estimation de l'Alexandris General Produce Association à 6 millions au moins, les sis de l'Etranger pour nos cotons, la baisse formidable de l'Américain sur le apport du Census Bureau, Is quasi certitude d'une 6valuation de 11 8/4 millions de balles par le Bureau d'Agriculture de Washington, tout cela ne produit susane impression sur notre marché. La spécula- 1on forte d'une position à la Bai-se dont elle exagère peut être les chiffres et qu'elle n'a encore exploitée qu'en partie, va de l'avant, soutient les prix et n's pas l'air de vouloir céd-r avant d'avoir obtenu gain de osase sur toute la ligae. Jusqu'où cels ira-t-il il serait difficile de le dire? En attendant, les cours sont à tal. 16 18/82 pour le mars et l'écart avec l'Américain ne semble pas inspirer de soucis aux maitres actuels de la situation, leur idée étant aussi que la question de la qualité, bien médiocre cette année, ne peat que contribuer à augmenter la valeur effective de nos cotons.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING.
div.p: An interesting account of the revival of terest in London in the Egyptian Mining Market was given by our London Financial Correspondent in our issue of Thursday last. As confirmatory of his statements we reproduce e following extracts from the latest London spapers to hand.
The Morning Post of last Monday re-

The Egyptian speculation practically do- minated the Mining Markets on Saturday, and he wild movements of Nile Valley Shares formed a feature from which not even the måd rash in Rhodesian copper properties detracted. But the whole of the South African Market, in the middle of which Egyptian Shares at present find a place, was in a whirl of excite- ment from ten o'clock in, the morning until four in the afternoon. The public seems to be coming more freely into the market, and though brokers report selling orders on behalf of clients who have nursed shares since the days of peace, they also tell of substantial buying from outside, supplemental to the professional support which is being extended to lesser known South Africans. The older South African speculations are comparatively neglected.
Another London contemporary, in its City article, states:-

For some time past this market has appeared as moribund as the mummies under the great glass cases at the British Museum. It seems, however, that a great deal of useful work has been done at the various gold mining proper- ties, and we are now able to form some opinion as to what that work has disclosed, and what its bearing is likely to be upon the fortunes of those companies which are best known to the British capitalist, viz., the Nile Valley and the Nubia Development Syndicate. The report of Mr. Mack, the managing director of the former company, contains news as to values which is little short of sensational. One shot brought down gold worth £4000. From 100lbs. of stone, 30lbs. of gold were obtained, and 180lbs. of stone yielded 67lbs. of gold. Mr. Mack consi ders that the initial difficulties of mining have now all been overcome. The pessimists, who have never ceased to declare that payable gold does not exist in Egypt, will have to modif, their opinions. Nile Valleys have had a con- siderable jump on the account, and were made :the medium of active transactions, which con- tinued in the Street until quite late last night. It is worth while remembering, perhaps, that no company can own mines in Egypt without Government sanction, and no flotation is re- cognised unless the Government is satisfied that the vendors' conditions are fair to share- holders, and that ample working capital has been provided. This is, perhaps, why the pro moter in a hurry and on the bounce has given Egypt such a wide berth.
The following is the text of the report referred to:-
November 21, 1904. To the Chairman and Directors the Nile Valley Company, Limited.

Gentlemen,-As requested, I left England in August last to visit your property in Egypt and to make certain arrangements with the Egyptian Government. I spent two months in the vicinity of Um Garaiart, and have pleasure in handing you herewith a short report on the present state of your mine.

The mine is under the management of Mr. John M. Beckwith, who has had a considerable experience in the management of mines, in Australia and elsewhere, who is ably assisted by Mr. Norman Whyte, Mr. Jackson (both late of the Waihi Mine, and certificated mine mariagers), and an experienced staff.

At the date I left the mine-viz.,November 7 -the two new Babcock and Wilcox 50 horse power boilers were erected and working, and the water was kept well under control by the large Evans sinking pump in No. 1 Shaft, worked by steam direct. A 5-stamp Fraser and Chalmers battery has been delivered on the Company's property at Allaghi, parts of which are already at the mine, the remainder being in course of transport. This battery, which is immediately to be increased to 10, consists of stamps weighing 1,240 lb. Taken on a rough basis, each stamp should crush at least four tons a day; so with the immediate working of five stamps some 20 tons per day should be

treated, or, say, 600 tons a month. The grading and foundation are completed, and the erection work is well under way. The battery should be finished and running shortly after the When the 9-in. beginning of the new year. Cornish lift is delivered, your mine will be fully equipped with machinery for some time to come. The oil engines are now used to drive the dynamos for electric hauling and lighting] purposes, and in this capacity are working admirably.

As I have already reported to you from time to time, both by letter and cable, the recent developments are extremely interesting and encouraging. There are at present, at grass and in sight, some 4,500 tons of ore ready for treatment as soon as the erection of the battery is completed, and this amount is being added to daily.

No. 1 Shaft has been unwatered and made secure to a depth of 152 ft., and sinking will shortly be resumed here to 200 ft. At the bottom of the shaft the reef is about 3 ft. wide, looking very well. At 150 ft., as soon as the mine was unwatered, a second, or intermediate, level was started north and south, and latest reports show that it has been driven 31 ft. north and 33 ft. south on the vein, which is stated to be 1 ft. in width north, assaying rather over 1 oz., and 2 ft. south. assaying 6 ozs. to the ton. This latter assay I consider a most encouraging feature, and confirms a previous theory I had formed, but not hitherto expressed, of the probability of the existence of a second shute, running parallel to the I shute just north of No. 1 Shaft, from which such phenomenally rich results have been obtained. The level at 108 ft. has been driven some 1,100 ft. on the vein, connecting all the shafts. The vein is highly mineralised throughout, and may be roughly averaged at a width of 2ft. for the entire length. In at least six places rich ore has been met with during the course of the drive, showing visible gold freely. It is proposed to sink winzes from this drive every 100 ft. or so, thus testing the vein and further opening up the mine.

You will remember that when sinking was sus- pended, last February, a winze had been sunk- a few feet north of No. 1 Shaft, from which s some £20,000 worth of gold had been extracted. The present depth of this winze is 30 ft., and, as visible. gold was showing in the north face, I decided, as soon as the mine was unwatered, to put in a couple of shots to test the richness. These shots brought down stone which yielded rough gold estimated to value some £4,000. One piece of stone alone weighed 100 lb., from which over 30 lb. of weight of rough gold were obtained. In all, 180 lb. weight of stone were dollied, which produced just under 69 lbs. or rough gold; so you can imagine the richness of the stone-in fact, the stone was some of the richest I have seen produced from the mine I may here mention that I brought down from the mine and banked in Assouan, for shipment to London, some £5,000 bar gold. Visible gold still shows freely in the north face of the winze; but I decided not to follow it for the present, as the drive at 150 ft. should develop it more economically.

This will be constituted the Main Shaft, and has now been stripped and timbered to 13 ft. by 5 ft. to a depth of some 155 ft. It is a three-compartment shaft-two for hauling and one for pump and ladder way-and is expected to cut the reef at 500 ft. or 600 ft. Cross- cuts will be put in at 200 ft., and driven to intersect the vein, and thence at every 100 ft. in depth.

Whilst in Cairo, where I remained for five days on my way home, I had very pleasant interviews with the Egyptian Government officials, resulting in the renewal of the pro- specting rights over the whole of your con- cession for a further period of two years- i.e., until April 30, 1907. The Government also agreed to grant a mining lease in respect of the property at Haimur (some seven miles from Um Garaiart), worked by your sub- sidiary, the North Nile Valley, Limited. In concluding this report I am pleased to say I consider that the initial difficulties in mining in a new country have been overcome. These difficulties consisted mainly of transport, lack of water, labour, and timber. The trans- port is working smoothly and well, and heavy pieces of machinery, such as the mortar-box for the battery, weighing four tons, are now transported to the mine. The water difficulty was overcome by the flow of water,in the shaft, and the condensers on the spot now provide ample for drinking purposes for both white men and native labour. There is an ample supply of labour upon the mine, prices ranging from P.T. 2 to P.T. 6 per diem, and, taken on
an average, the cost per day, all found (including food), works out at about 1s. 6d. per man per day.

Autiful supply of timber is procurable in the country, and is less costly than at the initial stages of the work, on account of the transport rates being now considerably lower. The organisation is now firmly established, and the mine itself appears more and more encouraging as developments proceed. A before stated, a 5-stamp battery will be running very shortly after the beginning of the new year; so that we may now reckon the mine will very shortly be making steady returns, and at the same time the development work will be actively pushed ahead. The present position of affairs, and the excellent erec- tion and development work done of late, reflcets the greatest credit on Mr. Beckwith, Mr. Whyte, and your entire staff, to whom I consider every praise is due. I had plea sure, before I left Um Garaiart, in promot ing Mr. Whyte to the post of Assistant- Manager.
I am, Gentlemen, yours faithfully, A. P. MACK, Managing Director.

div.head: IS IT IDRIS PASHA RAGHEB?
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Sir, I have been informed that a well-known Native gentleman, who is generally regarded by his admirers, in England as well as in Egypt, as a great philanthropist, etc., is, in virtue of an agreement registered at the Cairo Mixed Tribunals, the part-proprietor of the Cairo newspaper L'Egypte. Will you, Mr. Editor, or any of your readers, kindly put me right, by informing me if this information is correct. I ask this question in relation to the attacks lately made by L'Egypte on Mr. Tamvaco, for doing his duty towards the public and the commercial concern he represents, as well as on Sir Elwin Palmer and others in this country.

div.head: RUSSO-JAPANESE WAR.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Dear Sir,-Mr. Alderson, in his recent letter to you, appealed to the general public to find some means of stopping this cruel war. Has this been taken notice of, or have any I fear not, and very suggestions been made. much regret it. Petitions to the Tsar, signed by people of all nationalities, coming from every part of the word, would perhaps bring about what Diplomacy is prohibited to effectuate. Would the thousands of lists, carrying with them millions of voices entreat ing for the cessation of this wanton carnage, Has this not been done be disregarded? before? How can we remain so indifferent whilst thousands are being butchered, and why not make the attempt Now then, Egypt, set the example, and you, papers, help us to attain our aim.

div.head: YOU MAY HAVE IT AND NOT KNOW IT.
div.p: The kidneys are intended by nature to drain off the surplus water and the body's impurities. You know how well and strong and robust you feel when the kidneys are working right. You feel right in every way. But how do you feel when the kidneys become clogged and diseased ?
Tired, miserable, sleepless, nervous, restless, back lame, and aching and weak-can't stoop, can't stand without pain; rheumatic, gouty, dizzy, weak, no appetite, etc.

These symptoms and a thousand others come from the impurities in the blood, which sick kidneys have not taken out of the body. Doan's backache kidney pills tone and heal the kidneys, and enable them to take all these disease poisons out of the system. The medicine's effect is quick and sure; it does not act on the bowels, only on the kidneys and bladder:

The pills do one thing, and do it well. Doan's backache kidney pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists for P.T. 13 per box, or P.T. 71 for 6 boxes; or they may be had by post from the general agent for Egypt, Mr. Max Fischer, Hotel du Nil St., Mousky, Cairo.

Puccini's La Tosca was produced on Saturday evening before a large and brilliant assembly. The event possessed some especial interest, in- asmuch as two of the principals, in the persons of Signorina Pandolfini and Sig. Fiorillo Giraud, who assisted in the first and very successful production of the opera in Egypt some three years since, were again to appear in their respective rôles of Floria Tosca and Mario Caradossi. Although the production was an undoubted success, still we must con- fess to some little disappointment. Sig. Giraud did not appear to be in as good voice as we have frequently heard him. He was, however, rewarded with a deal of applause on several occasions and his acting of the part left nothing to be desired. Signor G. Polese gave us quite a novel conception of the now well-known Baron Scarpia, and is evidently of the opinion that if one has to appear fiendish a dash of amiability might prove a palatable addition. For Signorina Pandolfini we have nothing but praise. Her performance throughout the opera was of a very high order, and at the end of the second act her very difficult and at the same time most artistic performance created quite a storm of applause, the whole of the prin- cipals and the conductor being called before the curtain. Signor Gianoli-Galetti was, as he always is, inimitable as the Sacristan. The other minor characters were ably filled, and the chorus were well up to the work required of them. In the matter of staging there was an unusual lack of attention to minor details occasionally. For instance, a loose flapping canvas was a poor substitute for the usual reredos upon which our artist is supposed to be engaged; and Baron Scarpia must have been rather shocked at the earthquake effect consequent on the mere opening of a window.
The orchestra was quite up to the usual high standard, and in consequence of the indisposition of Signor Zuccani the conductor's bâton was very ably wielded by Signor G. Setti.

On Friday night we had Carmen, with a crowded house and Signa. Inna Monti-Baldini in the title role. The performance was decidedly good. Carmen sang excellently and acted well, and the orchestra did very fairly. Don José was not extraordinary as far as his voice went but worked hard, while Escamillo gave the Toreador's song with great spirit and vigour and was encored. The song in question is so frequently murdered that one can pardon an audience for encoring it on the rare occasions when it is really artistically sung. The other characters were good, but the chorus showed a distressing want of animation in several scenes, notably when Carmen, preceded and followed by an angry crowd of cigarettemakers, is brought before Zuniga. On Friday night the explosive violence which should have characterised the acting in this scene was absent, and the principals suffered in consequence.

div.head: SUDAN-RED SEA MAIL SERVICE
div.p: Khedivial Line's Express Mail Steamers leave Suez Docks every Wednesday, 5 p.m., arriving Port Sudan, Fridays, 6 p.m., Suakim, Sundays 3 p.m. Depart Suakim, Tues. noon, depart Port Sudan, Thurs, 10 a.m., arriving Suez Docks, Saturdays 3 p.m.

Departures from Suez after arrival of Brindisi Mail. Through carriages in connection with steamer attached to 11 a.m. train from Cairo. In connection with mail steamer a train (sleeping and dining cars) leaves Port Sudan, 8 p.m. Fridays, arr. Khartoum, Saturday, 8 p.m. From Kartoum, a train (sleeping and dining cars) leaves Tuesday, 9:15 p.m. arriving Port Sudan Wednesday 8 p.m. Passengers may remain night in sleeping cars.
